themes.label: Honorific Inscriptions
themes.rationale: The text is an honorific decree praising an individual for his diplomatic missions, financial contributions, and religious services for the benefit of the city.
themes.quote: τ] συμφ ροντα τ δ μω διατετ λεκεν

themes.label: Decrees
themes.rationale: The formal language regarding the 'interests of the people' and the listing of public services is characteristic of a civic decree.
themes.quote: τ συμφ ροντα τ δ μω

themes.label: Prayers and Invocations
themes.rationale: The text mentions performing sacrifices and making prayers for the safety of the citizens, women, and inhabitants.
themes.quote: το ς θ οισι π ντεσσι κα πα σαισι π ρ σωτηρ α[ς]

themes.label: Lists of Officials or Citizens
themes.rationale: The individual is mentioned as having served in the official capacity of a prytanis, though the document itself is a decree rather than a simple list.
themes.quote: πρ ταν ς τε γεν μενος
themes.ambiguity_note: The text mentions an official role but is a narrative decree, not a list document.

themes.label: Stele
themes.rationale: Honorific decrees of this nature were typically inscribed on stone stelae for public display in the city.

themes.label: Other Stone
themes.rationale: The inscription is carved on stone, likely local marble or limestone common in Lesbos.

themes.label: Fragmentary
themes.rationale: The text contains numerous lacunae and reconstructed sections.

rationale: This 2nd-century BC inscription from Eresos, Lesbos, is an honorific decree for a prominent citizen. The text details his diplomatic efforts as an ambassador to Rome (referred to as 'common benefactors'), his financial generosity toward the city's needs, and his religious piety. It specifically mentions his service as a prytanis and his performance of sacrifices and prayers for the safety of the citizens, women, and all inhabitants of the territory.
